discourse_list.title: Onboarding USDC as collateral to mitigate liquidity risk

content.content: Given the ongoing liquidity risk of Dai in an uncertain market, both the community and members of the Maker Foundation have been making noise in the official chat about onboarding USDC as collateral as an emergency measure to help mitigate this liquidity risk. Naturally this would need to be confirmed by governance, and go through an executive vote, but at this stage the Foundation is making the technical preparations to make this possible. I will be updating this initial post with pros, cons and points to consider presently. Please feel free to share any thoughts in the meantime. See this previous discussion for an overview of why this is useful: What's the point of adding stablecoins as collateral? A call is planned in which the Foundation Dev Team will be going through the code on the collateral adaptor for USDC. It’s currently slated for 4pm CET / 11 am ET / 3pm UTC Edit: Call has now concluded. Recording is available here. Proposal from Cyrus is now live, complete with community polling: Proposal for Collateral Onboarding of USDC  Pros   Helps to create Dai liquidity and push the Dai peg back towards $1. The mechanism of this looks like: Lock USDC → Mint Dai → Sell for USDC → Repeat.   Will allow Vault Holders to close their Vaults without eating the loss on the Dai peg being high against USD.   Will allow keepers that want to participate in the ongoing FLIP auctions to acquire the Dai they will need for those auctions.   Will allow keepers that want to participate in the coming FLOP auctions to acquire the Dai they will need for those auctions.   PR Response to fixing liquidity might be positive.   Cons   Reduces the ‘purity’ of Dai as a decentralized stablecoin - Dai is no longer backed entirely by decentralized assets.   Comes with regulatory risk - US Government could decide that dollar-backed stablecoins are not okay.   Comes with ‘blacklist’ risk - KYC/AMC could result in Circle blacklisting some amount of USDC used as collateral.   PR response due to Dai purity might be negative.   Points to consider   We need to decide on a Stability Fee - Note that this should probably lean towards the higher side, at some point Cyrus will share a risk perspective.   We need to decide on a Liquidation Ratio -  Note that this should probably be lower than ETH’s but should not be so low that a single Vault can mint all the USDC, at some point Cyrus will share a risk perspective.   We need to decide on a Debt Ceiling - Debt Ceiling especially is something that is to some extent more of a governance decision than a risk decision. We need something that is high enough to provide the required liquidity, but not so high that we take on additional risk.   Can we get away without oracles and hard-coding the price of USDC to $1? What are the pros and cons of doing so?   Is the collateral adaptor safe? There likely won’t be time for an audit.   This can be a temporary measure, we can lower the debt ceiling to zero once we feel the crisis has passed. (Note that this does require the crisis to actually pass and people to start opening ETH Vaults again.)   We need to decide on a Liquidation Penalty. As ‘debt-from-Stability Fees’ increases, Vaults can still be liquidated even if the underlying asset price is stable!   We need to decide on a Lot Size. If liquidations are going to occur, we need a lot size that makes sense for a stablecoin.   Other miscellaneous parameters? There are several of these that all need settings.
Right, I think that about covers everything I can think of immediately. Please @ me if you think of something else that I’ve missed that should go into the initial post.

Thank you for the intro LFW, Let’s all discuss this today on a community call at 4pm CET / 11 am ET / 3PM GMT, Invite details here:    Zoom Video    Join our Cloud HD Video Meeting now Zoom is the leader in modern enterprise video communications, with an easy, reliable cloud platform for video and audio conferencing, chat, and webinars across mobile, desktop, and room systems. Zoom Rooms is the original software-based conference...      Meeting ID: 723 226 374 I would also add liquidation penalty to your list of risk variables, as well as lot size for flip auctions, and dust limits. In terms of planning, if we determine this to be suitable for onboarding, we would consider putting up an executive spell after the current executive has changed the GSM to 4hrs, which occur tonight after 19:15 UTC, then we would need to vote on a new spell - let’s discuss this on the call shortly.

I’m actually not sure how important those parameters are. If we hard-code price then no one is getting liquidated. Even if we don’t the price of USDC is going to be very close to one anyway. Personally I’d be happy to defer to Risk for those parameters. Dust might be more important, that’s the minimum size of a Vault? I will add them to the post though.
Yeah, for completeness I was trying to think of all the variables to make sure it’s as transparent as possible. Happy for us to add/remove as you see fit.

I think it’s a good idea to add USDC as collateral, to enable liquidity to be added to the market for emergencies. Currently DAI is trading >1.07, there’s a lot of demand for DAI liquidity. Vaults will be able to lock USDC and mint DAI. They’ll be able to sell the DAI and provide DAI liquidity to the market. Why USDC? USDC has a lot of on chain liquidity and is also integrated with many defi other defi products. Also, DAI/USDC is traded a lot too. Price Oracle will be pegged at $1. They won’t be able to get liquidated from DAI/USDC price movements. My personal thoughts on Variables.  Stability Fees [sf+15%] - So I was initially thinking something lower. Then Cyrus mentioned 10% and made some good points. We generally want this to be mainly used when there is a great need for liquidity, and not used up for slight deviances in the DAI/USDC price or for rate arbitrage in normal circumstances. This could possibly raised higher, in emergencies compound has a 20% sf fee and dydx has a 50% fee. But unlike those, you can actually mint DAI with this maker facility. Vaults should still be able to profit as they shouldn’t be holding for a year. The main thing is that we don’t want the DC to be used on peg arbitrage when the peg is slightly out of sync, also historically it’s been very normal to have a 5% spread between USDC deposit rates and DAI deposit rates. Collateralization Ratio: 120-130% - This requires that vaults use some of their own capital to put on these trades. We want to require capital, so that someone with low capital can’t just utilize the entire facility. Also we don’t want them to get instantly liquidated from sf fees at a loss for maker. At 120-130%, vaults will be able to lever up 3.33-5x. Blacklist risk - This might not be that big of a problem. Compound also uses USDC and they might have an understanding with coinbase. Definitely not a problem in the short term. Debt Ceiling - 10-20m - this is a tradeoff between risk and liquidity. There is probably more than 10m in liquidity demand. The debt ceiling could be greatly lowered later (2m?) when the crisis pases.  I think even with a stability fee of 15%+ and a Collateralization ratio of 120-130%, there will still be a lot of demand for this facility when DAI liquidity is needed (current situation).
Oh! I completely forgot liquidations can be triggered from Stability Fees. We definitely do need to consider liquidation penalties and lot sizes.

In the short term, I don’t think we have to worry about regulatory/blacklist risk at all. In the longer term, this is just one type of risk among many. Agree on @LongForWisdom’s reasoning on debt ceiling (as required by liquidity, modulated by risk) No strong opinions on SF/CR/penalty/lotsize. I’m very worried about fixing the oracle to $1. Unless USDC/$ convertibility is trivial and has infinite liquidity (I don’t know if that’s the case), if e.g. USDC starts trading below par anyone could prop it back up at the cost of bringing down the DAI price (which might have been perfectly happy at $1). I’d much prefer an actual oracle, if doable quickly. Otherwise we should strongly commit to getting rid of the fixed $1 as soon as possible.
@sawkya How do you suggest finding the value of 1 USDC? Seems difficult.

I just want to encourage people to think through the implications of possible parameters when the DSR is greater than 0%. Or maybe we don’t care about this case because using USCD as collateral is just a temporary measure?
For sure, that’s a good point. SF for USDC needs to be kept above the DSR at all times.

Onboarding USDC as collateral to mitigate liquidity risk Collateral Discussion       If the collateralization ratio is 120% allowing 5x leverage then consider that the DSR could be paid on 5x the amount of USDC on which the SF is assessed.     With 1m USDC of capital they could create 4m DAI backed by 5m of USDC. They’re paying fees on 4m DAI. Someone else could earn the DSR on 4m of DAI.
Yep, @Jiecut is right. The SF to DSR is still 1:1, not 1:5.

To me it sounds like a band-aid to a deeper underlying liquidity problem which ought to be solved with careful consideration. Yes, supply from the side of the vault owners was limited at times, but the main issue was extremely low participation in the liquidation auctions themselves causing valuations that were too low. If you talk to the liquidated owners, you will find that they are mainly frustrated about the amount of lost collateral (for various reasons…), not the liquidation itself. Contrary to what seems to be the current belief, I’d say that the problem is therefore not that we didn’t have enough DAI, it is that DAI users were in fact trying to participate but unable to due to various reasons (no UX available, limited knowledge about the keeper system, 500 ETH fragments are simply too high a barrier for many people, etc.). People were begging for ways to get to participate and add liquidity! I am aware of the current efforts to solve this, but in my view we ought to first explore removals of these obvious barriers to the otherwise well-designed auction system first. As to the USDC proposal itself, there are new economical risk that can sneak in with such a solution and mixing it with an otherwise decentralized system … Lastly, I echo the sentiment that I am in this project for it’s pure decentralized nature and would not want to see it becoming inter-mixed with USDC. If it were, I would rather just want to stick with USDC altogether.

Concretely there are at least 2 exchanges with USDC/USD markets and more price feeds can be synthesized by going through other assets. That’s not great I know  It does seem that USDC convertibility is straightforward at the moment.

So as far as I’m aware coinbase allows convertibility at 1:1. I don’t believe there are limits on this either. I think we could get away without oracles in the short term. Long term it may be better to put some in, or it may not. I know dydx just prices USDC to $1.

I’m not sure USDC is a good way to help liquidity and the peg (decentralization). I think the current parameters (0.5% SF) will bring down the DAI price but I’m not sure how long it will take (maybe days maybe weeks). I’d take a different approach and allow negative DSR until almost all funds are withdrawn. Ideally, DSR should be baked into the protocol but I’m not sure how much work is needed (and is there a consensus about that?). It is not a bad idea though (USDC collateral) - it might be worth to have it ready.

This assumes coinbase always will convert without limits, won’t have reserve issues, won’t have delays that naturally lower the price of USDC just because of varying time preferences, etc. I’d rather us be distanced from these risks using a price mechanism than one day becoming a free money pump for USDC holders. That being said, I’m OK with a fixed $1 in the very short term, but we should do it with our eyes open: this goes against a lot of reasonable principles & is like sweeping some tail risk under the rug.

Given the context of this collateral onboarding: ensuring there is adequate liquidity for Dai in the upcoming MKR auction, I support fixing the price feed from Dai to USDC. The price feed for USDC can always be changed later on (taking the governance delay into account) and this offloads a huge amount of complexity for on boarding USDC today. The community can set a target to replace USDC’s oracles in say 21 days. At this point a governance vote could either remove the collateral from MCD or replace the oracles. Maker is trying to set up an auction for ~5.76M DAI in the coming days. For a sufficient amount of participants in an auction, this will lockup a multiple of that amount. However every DeFi protocol that encourages locking up Dai is reducing liquidity in the market. There are currently 37M Dai in the DSR (2M in Chai) and the uniswap liquidity pool has over 1.5M Dai. All of these won’t necessarily become liquidity to help with Dai demand even if Dai trades at an even higher premium than right now. We could very well see Dai going up to $1.1 again during the auction which puts an additional exchange risk on all of the keepers and will likely get priced into the MKR price (an additional dillution of MKR). @jiecut’s point I think is important:   Collateralization Ratio: 120-125% - This requires that vaults use some of their own capital to put on these trades. We want to require capital, so that someone with low capital can’t just utilize the entire facility. Also we don’t want them to get instantly liquidated from sf fees at a loss for maker. At 120-125%, vaults will be able to lever up 4-5x.   Without overcollateralizing USDC backed vaults, someone borrowing right at the liquidation threshold and subsequently triggering a liquidation will put additional strain on keepers.

is this not the worst possible time to consider hard coding USDC to be equal to $1. In these uncertain times forgoing the price oracle seems like a very risky endeavor. Just looking at the past week on coinmarketcap I can see that USDC has fluctuated between $0.97 - $1.06. Also in the uncertain times that we find ourself in i worry about how coinbase is going to fair in the bear market. What happens when the VC funds dry up?

@Andy_McCall I think it’s universally accepted that a price oracle would be superior. However, can USDC be added in time for the MKR auction with an appropriate price oracle? The discussion to have is to evaluate whether the benefits of USDC at a 1:1 exchange is more beneficial in creating short term liquidity than the risk it is adding by having a fixed exchange rate. I would tend to say yes, as Dai trading at $1.1 like it did on Thursday during an auction would be quite detrimental.

spin:  However, can USDC be added in time for the MKR auction with an appropriate price oracle?   This raises the question of what an appropriate price oracle is. I mean in the short term couldn’t you just use the coinmarketcap apis / uniswap price. Seems doable by thursday depending on how generic you’ve coded past oracles but i haven’t setup these things before and dont have insight. Honestly how much additional capital do we expect this to bring in? If you go with a 1% market cap DC as has been done with other collateral types in the past you’d be looking at about 6MM. Doesn’t seem worth the risk imo given that there is already 90MM+ DAI out there in the wild currently.

Andy_McCall:  If you go with a 1% market cap DC as has been done with other collateral types in the past you’d be looking at about 6MM. Doesn’t seem worth the risk imo given that there is already 90MM+ DAI out there in the wild currently.   This. I had been wondering myself, ~30 mil of the 90 is in the DSR, DAI minted from USDC probably wouldn’t be put in DSR since the rate is zero currently, so ~6 mil could very well help liquidity for the flop auction on weds. @LongForWisdom shouldn’t another con be an incomplete/rushed risk assessment? Also potential internal division could be more damaging to the project than just public perception? The executive yesterday rubbed some the wrong way. Adding USDC could elicit a similar response.

Getting this in by wed also raises another problem. Coinbase bank transfers take 7 days to clear. I can’t speak for everyone, but i don’t have a ton of cash just sitting in my coinbase account. Even if you had this live right now i wouldn’t be able to utilize it to mint dai by wed Maybe people have crypto laying around that they could utilize to fund the usdc purchase, but selling right now is going to mean people are realizing a ton of loss. I certainly am not sending my BTC in to convert to USDC right now. Concerning the 30 mil in the DSR. The current DSR rate (4%) is still SUPER good compared to what you can get in the financial markets currently. We’ll see how much stays in there once 0% goes live.

Andy_McCall:  Doesn’t seem worth the risk imo given that there is already 90MM+ DAI out there in the wild currently.   I believe the correct number is currently 46m, i am talking about transferable ERC20 token. Although maybe DSR lowering will trigger 30m exodus of “internal” dai.

I think using a $1 price for USDC, at least initially is reasonable. USDC is instantly convertible at Coinbase 1:1 for USD.  Any deviation is fairly arbitraged away.  Small differences can exist between exchanges due to exchange fees and network fees as well as ability to onboard fiat and fiat located on the exchange.  There is 400-700k of USDC liquidity on Kraken currently within 1% of $1.  As a market maker, with current instant convertibility on coinbase, arbitrage on USDC between other exchanges and coinbase is the easiest game around. With a high enough stability fee, in normal times, USDC will not be used often.  I think a good solution on the debt ceiling is to have it remain above 0, so that USDC can quickly be deployed to bring the peg back to 0 when large deviations happen in the future. A stability fee really depends on encouraging enough participants to enter into vaults.  I can enter into a synthetic CDP on Compound now by depositing USDC and borrowing DAI.  At 100% utilization that rate right now is ~18.4%, though it should drop post the 0.5% stability fee adjustment today.  DAI rates on dydx are much higher.  I think you want the stability fee for USDC to be lower than what borrowers of DAI can get on Compound and other platforms to incentivize people to open new CDPs and for people to have less incentive to lend on compound/dydx with lower utilization.  The question is how quickly will this instability pass and what rate will incentivize enough people to enter into vaults with USDC collateral.  If the peg reverts in a week, then 15% stability fee is fine.  If it reverts in 3 months, at 15%, its not such a good trade. Assuming a $1 peg for USDC and convertibility at coinbase, the real risk to vault holders is the dai peg moving higher (before it hopefully moves lower) and the vaults being undercollateralized and liquidated.  Mark to market losses with the hope that a reversion happens with no liquidation and before enough stability fees are accumulated to make the trade not worth it.

LongForWisdom:  Comes with ‘blacklist’ risk - KYC/AMC could result in Circle blacklisting some amount of USDC used as collateral.   I think that this alone makes it infeasible. The changeAdmin() function here can be called at any time (whether on purpose or accident) and can put the MKR system at complete risk.  USDC is a product of CENTRE. CENTRE’s founding members are Coinbase and Circle, but all this means is they have influence now. Even if we think that Coinbase and Circle act in a benevolent manner now, they are not required to do so in the future. Furthermore, they may not even have as much power and control in the future after onboarding additional entities. We have seen Circle acquire Poloniex. We have seen Tron and Justin Sun take over Poloniex. There is not much standing in the way of other acquisitions, consolidations, and transfers of power happening in this nascent space. A large enough player could effectively buy out Coinbase, Circle, or Centre and have complete control over USDC and subsequently some control over the MKR system. This risk is magnified by the current global economic uncertainty, but will continue to be prevalent long after stablization. None of this even accounts for state and federal regulatory actions that can occur.
Debt Ceiling will start at 10-20M and we can vote to remove it as collateral at any time. Not sure this is a short term concern. These are desperate times, calling for desperate measures.

I’ve just updated the OP with details of the action items from that call. We are expecting a number of parameter packages to be presented by Cyrus in the next few hours, these will be accompanied by polls. This is governance’s chance to impact the contents of the executive before it goes live.

If this facility gets too big, it would make sense to add other stablecoins. Otherwise it might just drag USDC price up. But I don’t think it’s that big of a problem currently, USDC/coinbase should have enough liquidity for our needs.

It is my opinion that desperate measures will result in a degradation of the long-term robustness and faith in the system, in the same way that the global reaction to 2008 caused a loss of faith in the Government and the Federal Reserve. Bitcoin grew out of this loss of faith and is why a lot of us are here today  and I worry that similar actions will allow for a new entrant to uproot MKR while citing the responses to last week, if they do not play out well. I am 100% willing to change my mind given enough evidence. With that said, my understanding is that the issues at hand are all rectifiable without compromising on the decentralization of the system. The following is my understanding of the issues and potential solutions. Feel free to correct anything I have wrong:  Problem 1 0-bid auctions are happening and forcing vault holders to lose their entire collateral when under-collateralized. Solution 1 Some say this is risk inherent with the system. Given that, there are still many solutions:  Onboard more keepers in order to make the auction system more efficient Be more clear about the potential loss of 100% of your collateral if under-collateralized Lengthen the auction times to allow for additional entrants in times of high gas usage (or other auction mechanism changes that I know are being discussed right now)   Problem 2 DAI is not pegged to $1. Solution 2 Adjust Stability Fees and the DSR so that it levels off over time. This will not be a short-term solution, but will stabilize the system in the long-run. Additionally, given that gasPrices are normalized, dapps are operating nominally, and general diminished hysteria of the crypto markets, I opine that arbitrageurs will continue to level the price by arbing DEXes and the DAI vault system.

@shane Your problem statements are way too simplified. The most immediate danger seems to be lack of dai liquidity. If eth quickly drops 40p, keepers won’t have access to enough dai liquidity, since CDPs are not willing to mint dai (from eth).

Problem 1: Too much Collateral Asset concentration risk - a systemic risk Description: The Dai debt ceiling must increase while the ETH debt ceiling must shrink in order to lessen the concentration risk, which is a systemic risk for MakerDAO.  In a normal scenario, you would think that Dai would trade at a discount to the peg since it is currently undercollateralized (by 5.67m according to whiterabbit).  But in this scenario, I think it is trading at a premium (1.067 as of right now: https://destiner.github.io/Off-the-peg/#/dai/usd) because multiple parties need Dai at the same time: those that want to top-up their vaults, those that want to be keepers, and those that want to participate in the MKR auctions. Solution 1: USDC would allow MakerDAO to increase the Dai debt ceiling and mint new Dai, which will help to rebalance the supply-demand imbalance.  Problem 2:  The upcoming MKT Debt Auction is causing an unnecessary surge in Dai demand Description: The Maker blog announced a date for the MKR Debt Auction but it didn’t announce how much MKR is expected to be auctioned.  Assuming the auction raises ~$5 million and assuming there are 4 bidders, then each bidder much acquire up to ~$5m worth of Dai before March 19th in order to participate and win.  That is up to ~$20m dai that must be acquired.  How much is $20m out of the total Dai liquid supply? My guess it is a lot, enough to continue pressuring Dai higher and higher. Solution 2: Push off the MKR Debt Auction until the Dai debt ceiling is fixed (see solution 1). Maybe I am already saying things that have been discussed elsewhere, I just don’t see it mentioned in this thread.
jernejml:  The most immediate danger seems to be lack of dai liquidity.   Why not try negative DSR to improve liquidity?
bit:  Why not try negative DSR to improve liquidity?   DSR cannot go negative. The lower bound is 0%.
psychonaut:  DSR cannot go negative. The lower bound is 0%.   Is that a constraint/constant that can easily be removed or some new code must be written so that the system can accumulate that income?

I understand. And the problem with another 40p drop is that because of this, the DAI price would spike, correct? Would this be resolved by arbitrageurs in a truly efficient market (of which we are far from)? Also @Jason, your response makes sense. Thank you for the details .
bit:  Why not try negative DSR to improve liquidity?   A question to those who want to solve illiquidity with a 0% or negative DSR: how does that solve the issue?

chaser:  A question to those who want to solve illiquidity with a 0% or negative DSR: how does that solve the issue?   not a supporter but i THINK i understand the premise. Currently there is ~25MM DAI locked in the dsr. That is about 25% of all dai that is not listed on any exchange and not available to the people who are going to participate in the MKR auctions. I THINK the thought here is that if we change the DSR to be < 0% this money will be withdrawn immediately and hopefully some of the 25MM finds its way to the open market for purchase.

Andy_McCall:  I THINK the thought here is that if we change the DSR to be < 0% this money will be withdrawn immediately and hopefully some of the 25MM finds its way to the open market for purchase.   Are you sure that would happen? People who left their dai in DSR after the last week’s events are probably very risk-averse, ignorant and/or clutching that dai. I’m not sure a 0% DSR would convince them to withdraw. A negative DSR maybe, but that’s technically infeasible, and would go against the ethical foundations of the MakerDAO. But let’s say you get them to withdraw. I think they would just hold on to that dai, it won’t enter the market.

I am new to this forum. I love the idea but the design of DAI is fundamentally flawed. There is only one fix. It is difficult but it must be done, otherwise MakerDAO is toast. You can add as many collateral types as you want, they could be short term fixes but mathematically there will always be a shortage of DAI. Every day, some DAI is sent to dead-end addresses or just completely lost, not to mention the under-collateralisation issue. So today, should all users decide to return DAI to their vaults and recover their collateral, there will not be enough DAI to handle this event. Granted, this is an extreme scenario, but the situation will get worse as time passes. You can’t keep relying on new users to create more DAI supply, that’s how Ponzi schemes work! The only fix is to introduce a negative Stability Fee, not just a negative DSR. When the Stability Fee is negative, the DAI that is created should be used to increase the total supply. This would easily balance the market. When the Stability Fee is positive, it keeps functioning as it currently does, i.e. reducing the MKR float. I believe that most of the time, in normal functioning and increasing demand,  the DSR and Stability Fee will be positive, but the they will have to go negative from time to time. This option has to exist. All this is probably currently not allowed or goes against the foundation rules, but this fundamental change has to happen. There is no way around it. Fix or DAI!

chaser:  A negative DSR maybe, but that’s technically infeasible, and would go against the ethical foundations of the MakerDAO.   2 false statements here:  technically infeasible against the ethical foundations of the MakerDAO (how about not keeping the peg and allowing collateral that can be blacklisted?)

Jiji:  The only fix is to introduce a negative Stability Fee, not just a negative DSR   I support that idea. The dev team should at least give us an estimate about the work needed to support that and it’s up to the MKR holders to approve it / activate or not.

This is a little off-topic.     Jiji:  You can’t keep relying on new users to create more DAI supply   Yeah we can. High DAI demand manifests as high interest rates in DeFi, and pulls more collateral into the system that we can charge interest on. We are a perpetual motion machine, and every DAI that is lost is more wind in our sails.     Jiji:  The only fix is to introduce a negative Stability Fee, not just a negative DSR   Charging interest is our business model. The stability fee is paid in MKR, not DAI.

Sure it’s off-topic. But that’s because I think the community should be discussing a real fix, not ad-hoc short term solutions that are doomed to fail in the long run. Should we create a new topic called Negative Stability Fee? Maybe. If you keep only relying on new users to create more DAI, at some point DAI will consistently trade higher than 1 USD, unhinging the peg, and people will lose confidence in it. All Ponzi schemes end badly. A good stablecoin needs to prove it can stay stable forever. This is unfortunately not currently the case for DAI. What I am proposing is that when the Stability Fee is negative, it is paid in DAI, increasing the supply of DAI. When it is positive, it continues to be paid in MKR. It is a shame, because the DAI model is very promising. But personally I will not touch it until it becomes mathematically robust. A Stability Fee that can go negative can achieve that.

bit:  I support that idea. The dev team should at least give us an estimate about the work needed to support that and it’s up to the MKR holders to approve it / activate or not.   Thank you bit. This does need to be done.

Jiji:  But that’s because I think the community should be discussing a real fix, not ad-hoc short term solutions that are doomed to fail in the long run.   Adding negative DSR is not technically feasible in the short-term. The reason we are focusing on short-term fixes, is because the Protocol is at risk in the short term from further extreme market movements. There are also alternatives to what you are suggesting with the negative stability fee. If the protocol is able to accurately estimate or identify the amount of ‘lost  dai’ then we could re-create that amount of Dai and allow it to be un-backed by collateral in the system. I don’t believe it’s accurate to say that there is only one fix to this problem. Starting a separate thread on negative DSR / fees is probably a good idea.

LongForWisdom:  The reason we are focusing on short-term fixes, is because the Protocol is at risk in the short term from further extreme market movements.   Fair enough, but maybe just beginning to officially discuss a negative fee can be more effective in re-anchoring DAI in the short term than adding USDC.     LongForWisdom:  There are also alternatives to what you are suggesting with the negative stability fee   I agree that this solution is probably not the only one, but if it can be implemented it is easy to understand, transparent, and effective.     LongForWisdom:  If the protocol is able to accurately estimate or identify the amount of ‘lost dai’ then we could re-create that amount of Dai and allow it to be un-backed by collateral in the system.   Maybe, but this solution is not market-based and not really transparent. Besides, “lost DAI” is not the only issue; there is no pure arbitrage that can easily re-anchor DAI when it is at a premium.     LongForWisdom:  Starting a separate thread on negative DSR / fees is probably a good idea.   Yes. You guys should. I’m done here

bit:  2 false statements here:  technically infeasible against the ethical foundations of the MakerDAO (how about not keeping the peg and allowing collateral that can be blacklisted?)    I disagree. As LongForWisdom said, a negative DSR is infeasible with the current deployment. And rest assured that taking away other people’s money is against the ethical foundations of the project, because it is theft. That’s what a negative DSR is. Not to mention it was launched and popularized as a mechanism for saving money. Making people lose money after that would have catastrophic consequences for the trust in Maker, so don’t even hope. (It is also, as I wrote a few posts earlier, probably ineffective for solving the problem we’re discussing in this thread.) On the other hand, the divergence of the peg from 1.00 is a natural and inevitable part of the system: it is a soft peg, never precisely at 1.00 (MCD white paper, Abstract).
